journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: High-resolution wear analysis of a ball-on-disc contact using low-activity radioactive isotopes

article-meta.aff: 1AC2T research GmbH, Austrian Centre of Competence for Tribology, Wiener Neustadt, Austria
2Atomki, Nuclear Research Institute of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences, Debrecen, Hungary
3Institute of Sensor and Actuator Systems, Vienna University of Technology, Vienna, Austria

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding author: AC2T research GmbH, Austrian Centre of Competence for Tribology, Wiener Neustadt, Austria. email: pauschitz@ac2t.at

article-meta.issue-title: INCLUDES A SPECIAL SECTION ON ADVANCED MATERIALS ENGINEERING: SELECTED PAPERS FROM THE INDO-AUSTRIAN SYMPOSIUM 2010

abstract.p: In this study, an advanced wear volume measuring technique making use of the radioisotope concentration method is applied to a ball-on-disc experiment, which allows highly precise online wear volume measurements and distinguishes among different wear regimes. Furthermore, the adhesive transfer of material from the activated specimen to the counteracting body was investigated with this method; it appears to be a promising technique for evaluating oil-protective capability. The experiments were carried out in a model tribometer following the ASTM D 6425 standard. A polyalphaolefin with zincdithiophosphate was used as lubricant. Two series of reciprocating sliding tests were conducted with different frequencies, 50 and 100 Hz. Results show a frequency-dependent running-in behaviour though the applied load was identical and constant. Using this precise online technique, a more accurate lifetime prediction can be estimated for applications like rolling bearings to which ASTM D 6425 refers.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The ball-on-disc setup is a long-established and reliable way of testing material properties either in the reciprocating or in the unidirectional sliding setup [1, 2]. For the investigation of the wear rate in a tribosystem, several standards and methods exist: in this research, the authors refer to the ASTM D 6425 – ‘Standard Test Method for Measuring Friction and Wear Properties of Extreme Pressure (EP) Lubricating Oils Using SRV® Test Machine’ with a linear oscillating sliding motion. This test is used as a screening test for lubricants used in systems with sliding motion.

AISI 52100 (named 100Cr6 in DIN-EN) is the most common material used in rolling-bearing applications and also in tools [3]. If a tribosystem exhibits only a very low wear rate, the detection and quantification of the wear rate are considerably limited or needs special test conditions. Golam Mostafa and Fremlin [4] have already performed activation on metal balls but their approach was based on the irradiation of the complete ball surface; in this study, just the surface in contact during the tribological test was treated (partial thin layer activation [5]), which allows an overall lower radioactivity and/or higher tribotest sensitivity.

The novel features presented in this research article are mainly given as follows [5]:
An advanced nano-wear measuring method (described in Section 2.2) which can be employed on commonly used laboratory environment without special safety or legal requirements, applied to a ball-on-disc contact experiment, allows an accurate and online evaluation of the removed material volume and an identification of the transferred material from the acting body to the counteracting body, even if both specimens are made of the same material.
The activation procedure was performed in a waydesigned to obtain two suitable radioactive isotopes, one from iron and one from chromium; in this way, the results obtained from one isotope were double-checked with the other isotope to realise a higher resolution limit.
The results obtained with the radioisotope concentration (RIC) technique suggest that a sliding path longer than the wear zone diameter leads to a different running-in behaviour and a higher wear rate, even if the overall sliding distance times load and the average sliding speed remain equal or the tests are performed at the same load.

sec.title: 2.1 Specimens
sec.p:
The ball-on-disc contact was chosen as the contact situation because it is typical for many standards and used all over the world for model tribometer tests following the ASTM D 6425 standard. Both the ball and the disc are manufactured using chromium steel AISI 52100. The material composition was checked using X-ray fluorescence technique and the results are reported in Table 1. Balls and discs used in this research are produced and finished according to the standard ASTM D 6425 (corresponding to DIN 51834) for ball-on-disc tests. The lubricant used in this study is a high-performance polyalphaolefin oil with zincdithiophosphate (ZDDP). Table 1
Composition of specimens
Element Mass (%)
Fe 97
Cr 1.5
C 1.0
Mn 0.3
Si 0.2

sec.title: 2.2 Wear volume measuring method
sec.p:
A measurement technique for wear measurement by radiation is known as radionuclide technique (RNT) [6]. Based on the RNT approach and the technology progress in the last decades, the authors developed an advanced measurement technique with higher resolution (compared on an equal low radioactivity level) and the one which can be used without special safety or legal requirements. To indicate this differentiation between the two techniques, the authors call their technique ‘RIC’, a method which consists of several components. The RIC-method uses the nVCT® device [7] with a scintillation radiation detector system (well type) to detect the removed volume flowing in the oil reservoir, as schematically shown in Fig. 1 (due to the closed test chamber, a detailed view into the test chamber is not possible). The conversion from detected radioactivity in the oil to removed volume is performed; thanks to the calibration curve shown in Fig. 2. In this study, the system was applied on a SRV® tribometer [7]. The activity of the specimen is well below (approximately 10 times lower) the legal free-handling limit concerning radioactive materials. Furthermore, the system used is based on an advanced borehole detector system in the oil circuit and can run with a total oil volume of only ∼50 mL, whereas the conventional RNT needs several litres of oil and the oil flows around the detector [8]. Thus, the advanced RIC borehole detector system is much smaller and lighter than the traditional RNT detector system. In contrast to the RNT, where a depth profile is determined, e.g. using a two-point calibration [8,9], the depth profile is determined with a high number of measurement points and in increments in the nanometre range. The experimentally verified depth profile is combined with a theoretical model of the specific contact situation between the basic body and the counteracting body to quantify a wear rate in the nm/h range. The new method is described precisely in the previous work done by some of the authors of this article, for example in Corniani et al. [10] and Jech et al. [11,12]. Only the combination of theabove-mentioned components of the method enables online wear quantification in the nm/h range. Fig. 1
Schematic test setup [11] and closed sample holder chamber
Fig. 2
Schematic depth profile of the RIC-method versus conventional RNT [12]

sec.title: 2.3 Wear test
sec.p:
The principle of wear measurements based on radioisotopes has been described already several times in the past by different authors [13–16]. The wear tests presented in this article meticulously follow the standards of ASTM D 6425 for high-pressure lubricating oils. The most important test parameters are detailed in Table 2. Two series of tests were performed changing only the stroke length from 1 mm in the first series to 0.5 mm in the second. The reciprocating frequency was changed accordingly to keep the overall sliding distance among the two tests setups (50 Hz in the first series and 100 Hz in the second; hence, the average speed is the same in both tests) equal. Wear of the activated layer is directly measured online by means of a radiation detector, while the wear process istaking place in the specific tribometer used (as described in the previous section). Table 2
Wear test parameters
Parameter Value
Ball diameter 10 mm
Disc diameter 24 mm
Load 300 N
Average Hertzian pressure at the start of the test ≈2.1 GPa
Average Hertzian pressure at the end of the test ≈0.72 GPa
Stroke 1 and 0.5 mm
Frequency 50 and 100 Hz
Oil and chamber temperature 50°C
Test duration 2 h

sec.title: 2.4 Thin-layer activation
sec.p: The thin layer activation (TLA) is generated with a beam of accelerated charged particles (i.e. protons, deuterons or alpha particles) from an accelerator in the MeV energy range, hitting the sample surface to be activated. Part of the material constituting the sample undergoes a nuclear reaction and gets transformed into a radioactive isotope of the original material that emits a characteristic gamma ray.

The main difference with the previous work stands in the irradiation procedure and the process of radioactivity [11]. The nuclear reaction followed in this study for the production of the isotopes is described in Table 3; the details concerning the isotopes are given in the same table. In the complex task of designing the irradiation parameters to suit our needs, a newly developed tool TLA2L by Takacs [17] was used. The same tool also calculates the resulting depth profile (i.e. activity per µm3) for all the produced isotopes in the sample after the irradiation from a theoretical point of view. Table 3
Irradiation parameters and radioactive isotopes obtained from the specimens’ irradiation
Particles Deuterons
Energy (MeV) 9
Beam intensity (µA) 3
Irradiated element Fe Cr
Produced isotope 57Co 51Cr
Main γ-line of the radioisotope (keV) ≈122 ≈320
Half-life (days) ≈271.8 ≈27.7

sec.title: 2.4.1 TLA and mechanical properties
sec.p: A quite common assertion against TLA is that part of the material, due to the nuclear reaction, changes its composition together with the fact that during the wear process radioisotopes produced from the original material are tracked instead of the original material itself (i.e. 57Co instead of natFe or 51Cr instead of natCr in this research). Equation (1) shows the ratio between the constituents’ atoms (Nnat) and the produced isotopes (Nisot) in the small activated region where the tribo-process occurs (1)

In equation (1), Na refers to the Avogadro number, Mm and δ the molar mass and the density of the constituent element, respectively, Avol the specific volumetric activity (measured with an high purity Germanium detector) of the isotope produced and T1/2 to its half life. In the case of the nuclear reaction natFe → 57Co, the most active sample used in this research had a volumetric specific activity (Avol) of ≈0.0025 Bq/µm[14] corresponding to a ratio of ≈106 atoms of natFe per each 57Co. Samples with (Avol) 10 or 100 times lower are still easily measurable. The presence of 1 ppm of atoms, differing by just oneatomic number from the others, has scarcely any or no effect on the tribological behaviour of the specimen.

A more realistic problem can arise from the localised heating of the sample during the irradiation process by the cyclotron beam. Microhardness tests (Vickers hardness 1, indentation depth ≈10 µm) were performed on all the samples used in this study. Each ball was indented five times on the wear scar, on the irradiated circular crown surrounding the wear scar and on the untreated ball surface. Results shown in Table 4 suggest that different parts of the balls have the same micro-hardness (taking into account the instrument error of 5 per cent) and hence no surface modification occurred. Table 4
Average Vickers 1 hardness of different parts of the specimens
Part of the sample VH1 hardness
Wear scar 859 ± 5
Irradiated area 872 ± 4
Bulk material 870 ± 3

sec.title: 3.1 Wear results fitting model
sec.p: Two main stages are normally distinguished in a wear process: a dynamic transitional state called running-in and a steady state wherein the specified parameters have reached a relatively stable level [18]. In an online wear measurement based on radioactive isotopes, the signal emitted from the radiation detector is converted through the calibration curve, described in Section 2.2, to wear volume. Radioactive decay is governed by Poisson statistics [19] and hence has a certain probability distribution; this fact, together with the noise-to-signal characteristic of the radiation detector, gives a scattered output. A least square fitting procedure has been implemented to analyse and compare the resulting wear curves; attention has to be paid in choosing a function to fit the data. The easiest option is to split the wear process according to the course of the wear signal into a certain number of stages and fit them independently using a linear function (i.e. constant wear rate in each stage) [20]. The model proposed in this study to represent the wear process considers the wear rate as an exponential decay decreasing to a positive and constant value W˙∝ during the whole test duration and with a finite positive slope at t = 0. Equation (2) [5] expresses the wear volume rate as a function of elapsed time with τ0 the exponential decay constant (2)
Integrating equation (2) gives the wear volume as function of time (3)

In equation (3) [5], constants a, b, c, d were constrained into ranges considering some physical boundary conditions, like background radioactivity at the start of the test, material wear rates <∞, etc. Imposing Wvol(0) = 0 = 0 leads to d = −a, resulting in onlythree independent variables in equation (3). Therefore, it can be concluded that a = −Kτ0, b = 1/τ0, c=W˙∝ and d = Kτ0 = −a. Constant c corresponds to the wear volume rate at time infinite, called W˙∝ in equation (2), and is normally called steady state wear volume rate when a tribological experiment is divided into several stages as previously described. Constant d corresponds to the offset of the wear rate at the reference time moment t = 0. Hence, equation (3) fitted to the experimental results through a constrained least square procedure (i.e. the wear curve), allowing a correct evaluation of the wear volume rate constants for the running-in and steady state stages. The resulting fit is shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 3
Experimental data and data fitting curve

sec.title: 3.2 Confocal microscope differential analysis
sec.p:
After each test, a three-dimensional (3D) image of the wear scar and surrounding area was acquired through a confocal white light microscope (Fig. 4(a)). Using special software developed at AC2T research GmbH [21], an unworn ball was superimposed on the acquired image (black line mask in Fig. 4(b)) and the differential volume (i.e. wear volume) in the selected region (white line mask in Fig. 4(b)) was calculated. Results obtained from this technique, called 3D microscope differential volume calculation (3DDVC), were used to compare the total wear volume at the end of the test with the measurement based on the radioactive isotope detection. Fig. 4
Confocal white light microscope images: (a) 3D image of a worn ball and (b) unworn area (black line) and wear scar (white line) masks applied for the differential volume calculation
The difference between the two techniques hasaconstant ratio (equation (4)) for all the measurements (4)

The above difference is caused by measuring the errors of each technique and by the fact that some wear particles (containing radioactive isotopes) remain in the lubricating oil circuit and/or in the sample holder and hence are not counted in the radiation detector.

sec.title: 3.3 Steady state wear rate
sec.p: The online wear measurement results using the RIC method allow us to distinguish between different wear behaviours during the experiment. As described in Section 3.1, the fitting procedure permits us to calculate the wear rate of the steady state independent of the course of the experiment.

In Fig. 5, results from the series of tests conducted with a frequency of 50 Hz and 1 mm stroke are compared with that conducted with frequency 100 Hz and stroke 0.5 mm; thus, both setups have the same test duration and overall sliding distance. The wear volume rate for the 100 Hz series appears to be lower compared to the 50 Hz test. A possible explanation of this behaviour is shown in Fig. 6. During a wear test with 1 mm stroke, there is no overlapping in the contact area zone, whereas with 0.5 mm an overlapping occurs (considering an average of 350 µm radius for the circular contact area at the test end); the suggested scenario is that in the latter case, wear debris are trapped in the contact zone, offering a sort of protective effect to the ball material. The ball encounters less resistance while sliding on top of the debris. These are more easily removed from the contact zone in the case of a longer stroke. Fig. 5
Comparison of the wear volume rate (in µm3/s) in the steady states of the two experiments
Fig. 6
Overlapping zone in the case of the SRV® test with a stroke of 0.5 mm compared to a SRV® test with stroke of 1 mm

sec.title: 3.4 Material transfer to the counteracting body
sec.p: In a wear process, different factors contribute to transfer a part of the material constituting the acting body to the counteracting body. Some of the causes for this transfer are adhesive wear, mechanical mixing, transfer film, etc. [22, 23]. In a scenario where both the acting and counteracting bodies are made of the same material, a wear measurement based on radioactive isotopes is the only way to show and measure the amount of material transferred from one specimen to the other. In this study, the radioactive specimen (the ball in our setup) was rubbed against an untreated sample (the disc). At the end of the experiment, the radioactivity observed in the counteracting body (the disc), even after an intense cleaning in ultra-sonic bath with xylitol, proves that some material was transferred among the specimens.

Figure 7 shows the relative volume of material transferred to the counteracting body compared to the total wear volume present in the oil at the end of the test. It is important to note that the material transfer refers solely to the transfer of iron which constitutes the ball matrix, while no proof of chromium transfer was found – although the technique’s resolution would allow detection below the amount of chromium expected from the stoichiometric composition of the material (Table 1). As a comparison, one single test with a poorly lubricating mineral oil gave results much higher in terms of transferred material: the volume of iron transferred to the counteracting body was comparable to the one found in the oil (Wtrans/Wvol = 100 per cent). A bit lower ratio (80 per cent)) was measured for the transfer of chromium compared to its wear volume. Fig. 7
Relative amount of material transferred to the counteracting body compared to the total wear volume of the basic body at the end of the test

sec.title: 3.5 Different wear behaviours
sec.p:
A few of the performed tests show a different wear behaviour from the one displayed in Fig. 3. The so-called running-in regime is very mild or missing and hence, with a test duration of 2 h (as given in ASTM D 6425), the test cannot be simplified into a no-equilibrium state and a steady state but rather is in a continuous transition. Figure 8 compares a test presenting two clearly defined wear regimes with one in which the running-in appears inhibited. Tests showing different running-in behaviour had a lower total wear volume and were excluded from the data analysis detailed in previous Sections 3.3 and 3.4 until further analysis can explain the different behaviour. At present, it can be just presumed that it is a different process in the formation of the tribolayer, mainly caused by a not completely dissolved ZDDP crystal in the lubricating fluid. Fig. 8
Tests showing different wear behaviours

These findings obtained with the wear measurement method, which is based on radioactive isotopes, are confirmed by the 3DDVC method resulting again in the ratio given in equation 4. Hence, Equation (3) can still be used to interpolate the obtained wear curve but it results in a small decay constant; the whole fitting is hence similar to a linear fitting among the starting and ending points of the wear process.

sec.title: 4 SUMMARY AND FUTURE WORK
sec.p: This study has shown the possibility of high precision online nano-scale wear volume measurement in a SRV® model tribometer with a ball-on-disc contact with sliding motion using TLA technique and an activation energy well below the legal free limits that was not previously applied to such setup. The possibility of measuring the material transferred to the counteracting body gives us a promising technique that allows the evaluation of the lubricating and protective behaviour of the oil and is not previously reported in literature. The tests carried out in the selected tribometer showed two different running-in behaviours. Earlier studies conducted with the intention of testing the material or its possibility of application or its properties usually determined the total wear volume at the end of the test by weighting the specimen orthrough an investigation using microscope. Measurements based on the proposed method allow us to follow the whole wear process online and accurately evaluate the actual wear rate and eventually the remaining life of a certain application.

The second part of the work related to wear analysis was funded from the Austrian Kplus programme and the Austrian COMET programme and has been carried out in the Austrian Excellence Centre of Tribology (AC2T research GmbH), Wiener Neustadt.

def.p: transition constant; as higher as much steeper running-in and faster transition to the steady state regime
slope constant; ‘positive’ slope of the steady state wear regime (corresponding to the wear volume rate at time infinite W˙∝)
constant offset of wear rate at the reference time moment t = 0
wear volume rate as function of elapsed time
wear volume rate at time infinite
wear volume obtained from RIC method based on TLA
